meanings.definition: To make something flat or level.
meanings.sent1: I used a hammer to flatten the nail into the wood.
meanings.sent2: She used a rolling pin to flatten the dough before baking.
meanings.sent3: The pancake was so round, I had to flatten it to fit in the pan.
meanings.sent4: His words seemed to flatten her spirits, leaving her feeling deflated.
meanings.sent5: The steamroller worked tirelessly to flatten the road surface.

meanings.sent1: The balloon started to flatten as the air slowly escaped.
meanings.sent2: After sitting on the book for a while, it began to flatten out.
meanings.sent3: The cake looked perfect in the oven, but as it cooled, it began to flatten.
meanings.sent4: The excitement in the room seemed to flatten as the bad news was announced.
meanings.sent5: The waves crashed against the sand, trying to flatten it into a smooth surface.

meanings.definition: To knock someone to the ground.
meanings.sent1: The boxer managed to flatten his opponent with a powerful punch.
meanings.sent2: The football player was able to flatten the defender and score a touchdown.
meanings.sent3: The playful puppy accidentally tried to flatten the little girl during their game.
meanings.sent4: The unexpected news seemed to flatten him emotionally, leaving him stunned.
meanings.sent5: The giant wave seemed to flatten everything in its path, including the sandcastles.

meanings.definition: To reduce the volume or intensity of something.
meanings.sent1: She had to flatten the music on her phone to hear the conversation clearly.
meanings.sent2: The teacher asked the students to flatten their voices during the exam.
meanings.sent3: The chef had to flatten the spices in the dish to make it more palatable.
meanings.sent4: The storm seemed to flatten the noise outside, making it eerily quiet.
meanings.sent5: The remote control had a button to instantly flatten the sound coming from the TV.
